title: 110_hr6172
content: The Act is titled the "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" and allows for the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds. The "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" allows for the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds through an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code. The "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" allows for the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds through an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code. Overpayments are reduced to satisfy past-due state judicial debts, with notifications sent to the relevant state agencies and individuals involved in joint tax returns. Overpayments shall be reduced to satisfy past-due state judicial debts before being credited to future federal internal revenue tax liabilities. The Secretary will apply any overpayment by a person against debts owed to State agencies or State judicial branches in the order they accrued, as notified by the State agencies. Rules similar to subsection (e)(4) will apply for debts under this subsection, including past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debts. State judicial debt refers to debts resulting from court costs, fees, fines, assessments, and restitution to victims of crime that are past-due but not collected. The Secretary will issue regulations for submitting notices of past-due State judicial debts, specifying required information and types of debts eligible for reduction. State agencies may need to pay a fee for this procedure. The Secretary will issue regulations for submitting notices of past-due State judicial debts, specifying required information and types of debts eligible for reduction. Any fee paid to the Secretary shall be used to reimburse appropriations for applying the procedure. States must promptly repay any erroneous payments made to them. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow disclosure of certain information to agencies requesting reductions under specific sections. Amendments are made to sections 6402(a), 6402(d), and 6402(e) to include subsection (f) for overpayment reduction. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code allow reductions for past-due State judicial debts and future Federal tax liabilities. The effective date for these amendments is for refunds payable after December 31, 2006.
